title: 112_hr3139
content: The Act may be cited as the "District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act" and establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds. The Act establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds, including qualified contributions to a natural disaster protection fund by insurance companies. The amendment to section 832 of the Code introduces a special rule for assets held in a natural disaster protection fund, excluding income, gain, loss, or deduction from being considered in determining gross income. Additionally, distributions from natural disaster protection funds are subject to amendments in section 832(b) of the Code. The amendment to section 832(b) of the Code introduces a special rule for distributions from a natural disaster protection fund, excluding certain contributions from gross income if returned to the qualified insurance company before filing. The amendment to section 832(b) of the Code introduces a special rule for distributions from a natural disaster protection fund, excluding certain contributions from gross income if returned to the qualified insurance company before filing its tax return for the taxable year. The 'disaster protection fund' is money, securities, or property held by a qualified insurance company in a segregated account designated as a 'natural disaster protection fund' in a bank located in the District of Columbia. The District of Columbia Commissioner of Insurance, Securities, and Banking requires that assets in the disaster protection fund be invested according to investment laws, with excess balance drawdowns distributed to the insurance company. The disaster protection fund assets must be distributed to a qualified insurance company in the District of Columbia by the end of the following taxable year, and no assets can be paid out except for qualified distributions. An insurance company in the District of Columbia must meet specific criteria, including being incorporated in the district, supervised by the Commissioner of Insurance, maintaining an office with a minimum number of employees, and being subject to relevant taxes and fees. The District of Columbia requires insurance companies to meet certain criteria, including being incorporated in the district, supervised by the Commissioner of Insurance, maintaining an office with a minimum number of employees, and being subject to various taxes and fees, including premium taxes and additional taxes on natural catastrophic risk coverage. The District of Columbia sets the rate for qualified contributions to insurance company funds, limited by the federal excise tax rate on reinsurance contracts issued by foreign insurers. The District of Columbia sets the rate for qualified contributions to insurance company funds, limited by the federal excise tax rate on reinsurance contracts issued by foreign insurers. A 'contribution' to the fund established by a qualified insurance company is defined as the total of net premiums or other payments received during a taxable year for coverage of qualified losses, not exceeding the amount reasonably at risk for the payment of qualified losses insured through the fund, less reinsurance on those risks, as determined actuarially on a multi-year basis. The term 'qualified distribution' refers to payments made for qualified losses under insurance or reinsurance contracts, spreading the risk of catastrophe loss, or excess balance drawdown amounts. The term 'qualified loss' refers to an insured loss on a United States risk that satisfies specific criteria, including events attributable to one or more factors. An insured loss qualifies as a 'qualified loss' if it is caused by events such as wind, earthquake, flood, tsunami, volcanic eruption, fire, hail, snow, or ice. An insured loss qualifies as a 'qualified loss' if caused by events like wind, earthquake, flood, tsunami, volcanic eruption, fire, hail, snow, ice, or pandemic. Total insured losses must meet certain criteria for catastrophe designation. Total insured losses exceeding $1,000,000,000 on an industry-wide basis can lead to catastrophe designation if the President declares a disaster or state of emergency, or if a Governor or chief executive of a State, possession, territory, or the District of Columbia does so. The Property Claims Services unit of Insurance Services Office, Inc., can declare a catastrophic industry-wide loss if a State, possession, territory, or the District of Columbia declares a disaster or state of emergency due to an event. The term 'excess balance drawdown amount' refers to the excess amount of the fund balance at the end. The term 'balance drawdown amount' refers to the excess of the fund balance over the total exposure to qualified losses under contracts issued by a qualified insurance company. 'United States risk' pertains to hazards, risks, losses, or liabilities related to property or activities in the United States or its territories. The term 'United States risk' refers to hazards, risks, losses, or liabilities related to property or activities in the United States or its territories. Exclusion of premiums and losses on certain Puerto Rican risks is specified, where premiums and losses with respect to risks covered by a catastrophe reserve in Puerto Rico are not considered in determining qualified contributions or losses. Contributions in kind to a fund are treated as a sale or exchange of property for its fair market value. Distributions of property other than money from a fund to a qualified insurance company are also addressed. Distributions of property other than money from a fund to a qualified insurance company are treated as a sale or exchange of such property, with any gain or loss excluded from the gross income of the insurance company. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations for this subsection. Additionally, there is an additional tax on certain distributions from a Natural Disaster Protection Fund under section 831 of the Code. The tax on nonqualified distributions from a Natural Disaster Protection Fund is increased by 20 percent for qualified insurance companies under section 831 of the Code. The tax on nonqualified distributions from a Natural Disaster Protection Fund for qualified insurance companies is increased by 20 percent. The bill increases the tax on nonqualified distributions from a Natural Disaster Protection Fund for qualified insurance companies by 20 percent. The amendments made by this bill will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011.
